japanese.content: ここに車を止めないでください
ここにくるまをとめないでください
koko ni kuruma wo tomenaide kudasai

translated.content: Please don't pull over the care here.

u.b: Grammar Point 1: Positive and negative requests

grammar_points.p: In this lesson we will practise requests where we ask someone else to perform an action. Here are some examples of this kind of request.

tr.td: ラジオを聞いてください - "Please listen to the radio."
リンゴを食べてください - "Please eat an apple."
かさを忘れないでください - "Don't forget your umbrella."
この本を読まないでください - "Please don't read this book."

grammar_points.p: The positive requests above are constructed by creating a sentence describing the action to be performed, changing the verb to a form called the "te" form, and adding the word "kudasai" after the verb. The "te" form of verbs is used to form compound sentences and shows up in many other grammar patterns which will be covered by later lessons.

The "te" form is formed by first changing a verb its plain past tense. If the plain past tense ends with a "ta" sound, change that sound to "te". Otherwise, if the plain past tense ends with a "da" sound, change that sound to "de". Unlike most other verb forms, the group that the verb falls into does not influence how the "te" form is made.

The negative requests above are constructed in the same way as the positive requests, except that a different form of the verb is used. This form is called the "naide" form, and expresses that the action indicated by the verb is not done. In all cases it is formed by simply adding the sound "de" to the negative non-past form of a verb.

A simple polite request for an object can be made by using the following pattern. For example, you can use this pattern when asking a friend to get something for you or when ordering food. In these kinds of requests, the object you are requesting is followed by the direct object marker "wo" and "kudasai".
リンゴをください - "Please give me an apple."
本をください - "Please give me a book."
